I used to work at NeXT. I know what it's like to have better technology, but still lose. We think the world runs as a meritocracy, but it's much more chaotic than that.
Exactly. I was fortunate enough to have one when I was in college. Imagine having your own Unix system with a laser printer. Epic.
what did you guys think of Joe's apology? I liked it. Rarely see humility from a Microsoft VP.

@robertlair I won't try to convince you. I'll just layout tools that and information and let you decide for yourself :)  The session is a brain dump of my last 12 months of research.
I agree. But it's a reality.

@timheuer oops, wrong use of the word operator. I meant the people building the sites in the first place. Like VirginAmerica.com. They have no native phone app, and their mobile experience doesn't exist. At least Southwest detects and gives you a minimal experience.
@jurdlow You are precisely the kind of person that needs to come to my session.

Does anyone think a win phone vendor can make better hardware than apple?
@seesharp I don't live there anymore ;-)
@seesharp lol. Bldg 40. Stop by anytime
Indeed. And Apple is really proud of that. Saw a session at the last WWDC and they were beaming about the "stability" of Obj-C.
Death is too strong of a word really. Backseat is better. Or "choice" if you want a euphemism.
~55% can do HTML5. 65% can handle SL4. IE6 is < 5%. Look at the slope of the curve, not the instance.
@seesharp yeah i have been translating backseat and choice as something to do until HTML5 is completely ready and the MSFT tools are finished for HTML5
And SL will never be on iOS. They tried in the past, but it's a non-starter. And also probably an impedance mismatch.
Bob, your tools are F12 in IE9 or the equiv in Chrome. And VI (or emacs if you're truly mental).
I did Obj-C and Interface Builder in 1988. It's hardly changed. Embarrassing really.

Scott, the reason I'm "skeptical" is that currently only a relatively small percentage of end-users have browsers that are HTML5 capable. As long as there are tons of end-users running XP and IE6 it's no better (and in many ways worse) than using Silverlight or Flash.
if desktop apps end up being HTML and Javascript I'm joining the Forest Service.
We shouldn't let the LCD make our tech decisions.

I guess there are always two ways to look at a thing...
The lack of SL on iOS is definitely it's weakest point... one which MS is unable to do anything about.
I was hoping to see near field communication, but that won't happen since they don't control the hardware platform.
Not to twitter. Stays here.
